results.title: Sexual Abuse Revelations Accelerate Sense of a French Church in Retreat
results.abstract: The abuse of more than 200,000 minors by clergy over the past seven decades has shaken the nation and what was once a pillar of French society.
results.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden

multimedia.caption: Easter celebrations in Paris last year. The Catholic Church in France has been weakened further than its counterparts across the world, especially in Germany and the United States.
Easter celebrations in Paris last year. The Catholic Church in France has been weakened further than its counterparts across the world, especially in Germany and the United States.

results.title: A Surprise Sports Hero Broadens Italy’s Image of Itself
results.abstract: Lamont Marcell Jacobs, a mixed-race Italian athlete, was not well known heading into the Olympics but he emerged as the world’s top sprinter, with two gold medals.

results.title: Chinese Journalist Detained After Criticizing Government-Sponsored Blockbuster
results.abstract: The police arrested Luo Changping on Thursday, two days after he questioned China’s role in the Korean War, the subject of China’s box office hit “The Battle at Lake Changjin.”
results.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Amy Chang Chien

multimedia.caption: “The Battle at Lake Changjin,” which recounts a brutal American defeat in the Korean War, has dominated the box office in China on its opening week.

results.title: Austria’s Government Teeters as Sebastian Kurz Faces Corruption Probe
results.abstract: The future of the chancellor’s coalition looked increasingly uncertain after prosecutors opened a criminal investigation on suspicion that he paid off pollsters and journalists.

results.title: ISIS Bomber Kills Dozens at Shiite Mosque in Northern Afghanistan
results.abstract: The Islamic State Khorasan claimed responsibility for the attack in Kunduz, continuing its campaign of predation against the Hazara Shiite minority into a new era of Taliban rule.
results.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Wali Arian
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: Turkish Philanthropist Goes to Trial Again in a Widely Condemned Case
results.abstract: Lawyers and human rights groups denounced the trial as a farcical attempt to prolong the detention of dissidents on trumped-up charges already found to be inadequate.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

results.title: They Had the Vaccines and a Plan to Reopen. Instead They Got Cold Feet.

results.title: Court in Argentina Dismisses Charges Against Kirchner in Bombing Case
results.abstract: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, now the vice president, had been accused of conspiring with Iran to thwart an investigation into a 1994 attack on a Jewish center in Buenos Aires.

multimedia.caption: Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner last month in Buenos Aires. The ruling late Thursday is the latest legal victory for Mrs. Kirchner, who was president of Argentina from 2007 to 2015.

results.abstract: Poland argues that its courts should supersede the bloc’s top court. The E.U. sharply disagrees.

results.title: China’s Power Crunch Exposes Tensions Ahead of Key U.N. Climate Summit
results.abstract: Keeping global temperatures from dangerous levels means China must pivot away from coal immediately. Its soaring energy demand and rolling blackouts mean it probably won’t.
results.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Lisa Friedman

multimedia.caption: Construction on the Zhongtang gas-fired power plant in Dongguan, China, one of several new gas plants being built in the area to meet the country’s energy needs as it pivots from coal.

results.title: Bitcoin Preaches Financial Liberty. A Strongman Is Testing That Promise.
results.abstract: As cryptocurrency enters global finance, an experiment in El Salvador could offer clues on whether it will bring a more libertarian economy or greater government control.

results.title: In Iraqi Elections, Guns and Money Still Dominate Politics
results.abstract: Iraqis vote Sunday in parliamentary elections called a year early, after huge anti-government protests. Most parties are appealing to voters on the basis of religious, ethnic or tribal loyalty.

results.title: Germany’s Coalition Dating Game Starts to Get Serious
results.abstract: The Social Democrats and two other parties took the first step toward forming the first three-party coalition since the 1950s, but resolving their differences will be hard.

results.title: Florida’s Board of Education approves cutbacks to 8 school districts over mask mandates.
results.abstract: Thursday’s decision means that the districts could face cutbacks that are equal to their school board members’ salaries for requiring students and staff to wear masks.

results.title: Nobel laureate from Russia says he would have chosen a different Russian.
results.abstract: Supporters of the jailed Russian opposition leader Aleksei Navalny say he should have won the Nobel Peace Prize. The Russian journalist who won, Dmitri A. Muratov, agrees.

results.title: An E.U. official blames Russia for delays in approving the Sputnik vaccine.
results.abstract: Moscow has criticized the bloc for not yet approving the Russia-made vaccine, but the E.U. ambassador said the timing was not political.

results.title: Awarding the Nobel to journalists recognizes the growing repression of media.
results.abstract: Around the world, journalists find themselves under growing pressure. An estimated 274 journalists were imprisoned for their work in 2020, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists.

results.title: Journalists Maria Ressa and Dmitri Muratov are awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
results.abstract: The two, who lead independent news outlets in the Philippines and Russia, despite government repression, were recognized for “their courageous fight for freedom of expression.”

results.title: Some of the Nobel committee’s previous picks have been called into question.
